Remove chiles from heat and soften in a bowl with 2 cups very hot water for 15 minutes. Put chiles, tomatoes, onions, garlic, oregano, epazote, and bouquet garni in a pot with 2 cups water and simmer over low heat for about 30 minutes. Remove from heat. Discard bouquet garni. Puree sauce in small batches in a blender to make a smooth paste.

In a nonstick pan, toast the sesame seeds until golden, then place in a bowl and set aside to cool. In the same pan, toast raisins over medium heat until plump, about 5 minutes. Cool. Grind seeds with a mortar and pestle or in a small electric grinder. When you have a smooth paste, add raisins and then continue to grind until smooth again.

Combine the puree with the sesame-raisin paste and the chicken stock and simmer over low heat for 2-3 hours, stirring occasionally. Season with salt and pepper to taste. The mole should have a thick, smooth consistency.

c2a23935a692a55c8fb73743cac0f0df5d64af69.name: Thai Chicken with Basil Stir Fry
c2a23935a692a55c8fb73743cac0f0df5d64af69.description: Chicken strips in a basil and coconut milk sauce are served over jasmine rice.

ingredients.ingredient: skinless, boneless chicken breast halves - cut into ½ inch strips

c2a23935a692a55c8fb73743cac0f0df5d64af69.author: GABRIELLEDC

original.headline: Thai Chicken with Basil Stir Fry
original.description: Chicken strips in a basil and coconut milk sauce are served over jasmine rice.

video.description: Skip the restaurant and bring home the great Thai flavors you and your family love—and make it just as spicy as you like! Combine coconut milk with soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, fish sauce and red pepper flakes. Then cook onion, ginger and garlic in a hot skillet or wok. Add chicken strips and the coconut milk sauce and when reduced, add mushrooms, green onion and lots of basil. Serve over jasmine rice and enjoy a balanced and delicious meal!
video.name: Thai Chicken with Basil Stir Fry

original.name: Thai Chicken with Basil Stir Fry
recipeIngredient: 2 pounds skinless, boneless chicken breast halves - cut into 1/2 inch strips

recipeInstructions.text: Bring rice and water to a boil in a pot. Cover, reduce heat to low, and simmer 20 minutes.
In a bowl, mix the coconut milk, soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, fish sauce, and red pepper flakes.

In a skillet or wok, heat the oil over medium-high heat. Stir in the onion, ginger, and garlic, and cook until lightly browned. Mix in chicken strips, and cook about 3 minutes, until browned. Stir in the coconut milk sauce. Continue cooking until sauce is reduced be about 1/3. Mix in mushrooms, green onions, and basil, and cook until heated through. Serve over the cooked rice.

review.reviewBody: I did add some stuff. I reduced the chicken from two pounds to half a pound. I think most recipes overdo the meat for my taste. To make up for the reduced meat, I added what I had: broccoli, bell pepper, and snow peas. If I was doing it again, I think I'd increase the sauce. Not sure I'd double it. I'll have to play with it to see what works. On the other hand, from my experience with the changes I made, I feel pretty certain the original recipe would have been just fine. One thing the changes I made did I think was to take away some of the spotlight on the basil.

This is terrible. It has all the normal ingredients you would expect in a Thai dish and I followed the recipe exactly as written . It had a strange taste that even my husband couldn’t handle and he eats everything. Not at all authentic

I did tweak this a bit, but I like this recipe a lot because it allows room for some personalization. First, I blended the sauce ingredients together in the vitamix and added a huge handful of cashews to it. I'm not sure this changed the flavor all that much, but it did make the sauce thicker, which some reviewers had complained about this recipe being too soupy. I agree with many others who said they used the whole can of coconut milk, I think this is absolutely necessary! I did not experience a soupy result at all, after reducing. I thought it was just perfect. I reduced the rice vinegar by 1 TB and juiced one lime into the wok at the very end of cooking instead. Also, I did add about 2 TB of sugar during cooking, which I'm glad I did. I did not find the fish sauce to be too salty or too overpowering (just don't try the sauce before cooking it!). Anyway, we loved it. Everyone went back for seconds, even my toddler!
I used what I had on hand. Replaced the following: shallots for onion, whorshehire sauce for fish sauce, red chili sauce for red pepper flakes. Topped rice with Swiss chard then the chicken stir fry.

For how easy this recipe was, I was blown away with the depth of flavor. The ginger really shines. I stuck pretty close to the recipe, only subbing gochugaru for red pepper flakes, since it goes so well with asian cuisine. Will be making again!
I cut the red pepper flake amount in half and I didn't have shitake mushrooms on hand so replaced them with snowpeas since I had them. Oh, and I added a Plymouth gin martini. Perfection!
Delicious!! I did add a little sugar, but otherwise followed the recipe. Will definitely make this again soon!
Had great flavor. Next time, I’ll take the onion, garlic, ginger mix out of the pan. Add a bit more oil, then sauté the chicken. Mine didn’t brown at all.
Delicious! I added red bell pepper which enhanced the taste.
This was so flavorful, healthy and easy! It’s one of our new faves!
Quick, easy and really delicious!
So yummy!!! I cook this all the time!! Great recipe.

This recipe was very good. Easy as pie to make and makes in one pan. (except for the rice). I made this, we ate, and kitchen cleaned in less than an hour. Apprx 40 minutes. Both the time and meal were all very good. Thanks Allrecipes.
Delicious!

Alone, this is a nice chicken stir fry. The flavors are balanced and it's delicious as it is written. You will do fine just making this as is! If you are looking for the Thai flavors, some simple substitutions will get you there. If you just use the Thai ingredients, ie, ginger (galanga), Thai basil, vegetable oil instead of evoo, Thai bird's eye chili peppers, Thai fish sauce (not absolutely necessary, but nice if you have it) and kiffer lime leaves as well as Thai soy sauce (if you happen to have) you will have better than restaurant results.

Having spent lots of time all over Thailand, a few cooking classes there and LOTS of Thai cooking, I appreciate the differences in many Asian dishes and recipes. The use of specific ingredients( when possible) takes recipes to a whole other level almost always making them better than restaurants.
Easy to make and tasty. I added two ingredients: juice from half a lime, and about 1 Tbsp of Thai Sweet Chili Sauce from my local Walmart (instead of pepper flakes).
Delicious! Made it for a group of friends and everyone love it!
Very flavorful, you can very the pepper flakes if you don't want a milder version but I followed the recipe exactly and loved it.
Delish!
Easy to make. Time spent is accurate. Only con...I thought it was a little salty. I would use low sodium soy sauce. Otherwise, excellent.
use less fish sauce. Otherwise it is great. Made this many times now.

Omitted fish oil so then it needed some salt. Going to substitute soy paste for the fish oil next time. Love the heaps of basil, a great dish. Can also make with Tofu instead of chicken, no alteration to directions needed.
I absolutely love basil, but even using half it was too much.
The recipe is good except that it uses too much fish/soy sauce. The amount specified here makes the dish way too salty.
I couldn't find shitakes so I just used 8 ounces of sliced mushrooms. Turned out great!

After cutting the chicken into bite-sized pieces, I conditioned it with 2 tsp baking soda and let it sit while chopping up the veggies we used. Before cooking the chicken, I rinsed it well under cold water and used a paper towel to dry it as best I could. This gave the chicken a velvety texture and it wasn't dry or chewy at all.

I used the veggies in the fridge, so ours was a little different. I had fresh broccoli, onion, and red and yellow peppers so that's what I used. 

Followed the advice of other reviewers and used the whole can of full-fat coconut milk. 

I began by sautéing the veggies in sesame and olive oils in my very hot wok. After they were crisp-tender, I took them out and added a touch more sesame oil. Then stir-fried the chicken until it had a nice browned crust on both sides. Added just the soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, fish sauce, and garlic chili paste (it's amazing for heat!) just as the chicken was almost done cooking; then added in the coconut milk and scraped up the bottom of the wok. I didn't have fresh basil this time so I just used dried (next time I will definitely try to use fresh, but dried gave it good flavor, too). Added the veggies back in and stirred well to get them in the sauce. Covered the wok and let the broccoli steam while I juiced 3 small limes and mixed in cornstarch to the lime juice. 

After the broccoli was steamed but still just a touch crisp, I added in the lime juice-cornstarch slurry and cooked it up until the sauce thickened a
Made as is.
CFC
We love Thai but nobody enjoyed this.
Not overly impressed with this recipe. Won't be making again (I'll look for a more traditional one).

I added shredded carrots that I had on hand. I would like to try the holy basil that I was hearing about next time. Yes I will definitely make this again. I squeezed a little lime on it before eating.
This was great! I reduced the crushed red pepper to make it less spicy. Left out the mushrooms because we didn't have any. I will make this again, and experiment with adding other vegetables.

I followed this recipe pretty closely with a few minor changes. I used a little less fish sauce, a little more soy sauce, a little more of the coconut milk, boneless chicken thighs cut in bite size chunks, & included shallots. I didn't add the basil to the dish until I plated & I was so glad I did that. My husband and I both thought it tasted really good. We'll definitely make it again!

This was an excellent change of pace as I don’t often cook this type of cuisine. I will definitely be adding this to my monthly meal options. I loved the flavor and the ability to add-on with various veggies on hand. I’m a huge fan of Spicy and with this recipe the more the merrier! With the base of ingredients to create this you can simply modify this recipe to make it your own. I used more of the coconut milk than called for because, Sauce!!! The substitution of chili oil for cooking the chicken and then a dash or two of siratcha as well as some brown sugar into the coconut milk mixture took it to the next level for me. I highly recommend splurging on the Jasmine rice as an accompaniment.

This was really good. I used Thai basil and the flavor really came through. I would have sliced the chicken a little thinner next time like the size the recipe called for so it would cook faster. I used low fat coconut milk and I think it was fine. I just had to cook it down a bit more. I will definitely put this recipe on my list of make again recipes.

I made this recipe because it looked different than your average stir fry. I like the flavor of Thai dishes, but never really attempted them at home. I followed the recipe very close to the recipe provided and the whole family really enjoyed this dish. I was actually surprised to see my picky son liked it. I substituted baby bella mushrooms and it was still good. I added the mushrooms too late in the process and by the time they were cooked the way I like them , the chicken got cooked more than needed and wasn't as tender as it should have been. I will be making this again and will be better the next time.
Delicious. Don't change a thing.

If I had this at a restaurant, I would be a happy camper! This was the first time I cooked with some of these ingredients, and it turned out great. Like others, I used the whole can of coconut milk. I also added more heat by using some garlic chili sauce (about 1 T.), and sweet chili sauce (about 2 T.). I think the sweet chili sauce made a big difference because it added some of sweetness which otherwise would have taken the finished dish down a notch. As it was, I also added some agave nectar when it was done because it seemed to need a little more of that signature Thai sweetness. I also put in more basil and added some rice noodles. Boy, this really was good. Only thing I might add next time would be some chopped peanuts.
very tasty
Have made this dish several times and love it!

I played around with the sauce a bit. Thai basil is a must, I won’t make it if I can’t find it. I also added oyster sauce instead of fish sauce and a few teaspoons of green curry paste. If you have a stalk of lemongrass throw it in too.
I just made this tonight without any changes and it was fantastic! My son is home from spending a long time in Thailand and he even said it was very good! Thanks for sharing!
Easy to make and delicious too!
Quick, easy and delicious. I added some extra vegetable to the stir fry.
HOLY TASTEBUDS this is good!!!!
I would double the sauce, it is so good with the rice.
Only had dried basil available but put in half the recipe's amount. It could have done with a little less. Still loved the flavors.
Very yummy. Works well for people with diabetes and for those who are trying to elevate their ketones.
Very yummy. Works well for people with diabetes and for those who are trying to elevate their ketones.
I am eating this dish as I write this, It is very tasty and will definitely make it again. My only change was the mushroom, just used a regular one I had in the fridge.
Great easy dish. I added pre cooked chicken. Still great tasting. I also addeda bit more red peper.
Followed recipe to a T it was 4eaaly good and plan on making again probably would try fresh chilis next time but over all really good
Definitely will make it again! Doubled the recipe - really delicious!!!
No changes, very yummy
Awesome!
Very east and tasty. This will be added to my weekly meals.

I actually made the recipe without looking at the reviews. Only a few adjustments – subbed zucchini for mushrooms since my husband just doesn’t like them, omitted green onions for same reason. Would add more salt and flavoring. Oh and used thighs instead of breasts.
I made this and substituted the fish sauce for oyster sauce as I was worried about the salt content. It was absolutely delishous and do quick and easy to make!
Awesome, used shrimp and added snow peas. Flavors were great.
Very good; I used fresh cilantro instead of basil and the family enjoyed it. Also used reduced-sodium soy sauce and it was plenty salty.
Very tasty! I used ground chicken because that was all I had on hand, as well as a whole can of coconut milk and it turned out really nice. Thanks for sharing!
I will definitely make it again. It was really good!

Delicious! I made the recipe exactly as written, except for substituting regular mushrooms for the shiitake mushrooms, because that's what I had on hand. I sauteed them along with the onion, ginger and garlic. I also used the whole can of coconut milk, as we like a lot of sauce. I used low fat coconut milk - I don't recommend it. It was watery and lacked the flavor of the full fat version. I'll definitely make this again, but with the full fat coconut milk. Thanks for the recipe!
I followed the recipe exactly. Great dish. Made it with lettuce wraps. Everyone loves it.
No changes. Excellent.
Great meal, I'll make it again.

The second time I made this I added 1 tbs of brown sugar, 1 tbs zest of lime and 1 tbs of lime juice - loved the flavour it added. I also mix all of the sauce ingredients together and only add in once the veggies and chicken are ready. So no browning of the garlic and ginger root before.

My family loved this recipe. It seemed seemed to be missing a little something sweet so I added 3 tablespoons of mirin and it was perfect. As an added twist, instead of eating it over rice we ate it over whole grain ramen noodles. Thanks for sharing!
very yummy!
Made as is with Italian basil. Turned out great with unique taste. Next time I'll use 2 tbsp of rice vinegar though.
I bought a package of mushrooms,a 1/2 pound and used em all. Wonderful!!!
A bit too much vinegar for my tastes. Dial it back a bit. I like sour/savory things but this seemed a little out of balance.

Loved this dish, whether it's authentic or not. Added extra coconut milk and didn't reduce much in fact put the lid on it the first few minutes cause I like it to be saucy, used chili paste instead of flakes about two tbls. Haven't any access to any thai basil so used Italian sweet and used cremini mushrooms cause that's what I had... Also had leftover steamed shrimp I added to it as well and just loved it
My wife said "This is really good!" Don't need a better review than that.
Yummy!

I loved this one. My husband did not like it at all.
I will make it when he is not here!

This was delicious. It does require some time to do all of the chopping so allow for that. Also, we do not care for fish sauce so we substituted peanut butter in the same amount. To keep it healthy, we used a lower fat peanut butter. I recommend this recipe. Super good and extremely healthy. Thanks!

The dish doesn't taste at all of coconut milk. It is salty, sour, and a little bit slimy. The sour would have been better coming from lemon grass (lighter, better taste, a touch of sweetness), the fish sauce was wholly unnecessary, coconut cream would have made a thicker sauce, and the vinegar added nothing positive. However, it is so inconsequential in taste I don't think it's worth the effort to make it again to try those edits.
Even after I added the rest of the can of coconut milk, I couldn't taste it past the odd salty, sour combo.
No changes and will make again
This is simply delicious!!! I skipped the fish sauce since I don't like it anyway. The flavor was just amazing, I could eat this everynight. Can't wait to make it again. I may spice it up a bit.
Delicious! I added Red Curry paste and asparagus!

This was very simple to make and since I'm diabetic I mixed my rice with riced cauliflower. To make it even easier,,I used frozen preprepared cauliflower. To add to the veggies, I added ginger carrots with a little sweetness on the side. I'm sure there are more appropriate Thai vegetables, but I'm not aware of them now. I will have to research that. The chicken was great and it was easy Asian food to modify for my diabetic diet.
Easy to make and very tasty!

I make Thai food at home at least once a week. As per other reviewers, I would say that this dish as written is American food. I think the idea for this recipe is good but one needs to use other ingredients to make it Thai. Use galangal if you can find it. It is expensive so don't waste it. Once found, slice it and use part for this dish. The rest can be sliced into 1/4" slices and put into a jar filled with rice wine in the refrigerator for a month for future use. Use peanut oil, never olive oil in Thai dishes. Thai basil is a must, not Italian basil. The flavors are very different. For a more authentic touch use ground chicken or pork instead of diced chicken breast. Skip the pepper flakes and go for sliced chilis of whatever heat you wish. And lastly, want to feel like you are on the beach in Phuket ? Fry an egg sunny-side up and put an egg on each portion when serving this dish served atop Thai jasmine rice. Thanks for your submission of this dish, it has sparked many home chefs to experience another country's food without the price of an airplane ticket.
It was good. I added eggplant. Wish it was a bit spicier.

I cut my breast in half then sliced it to make thinner pieces of chicken. I did not have garlic salt or chili oil so didn't use. I think it would too salty with more salt anyways. I used two red Thai chili peppers for the heat. I lost my basil in the fridge so I used cilantro instead. I will definitely make this again.

I've made this a few times, the first two exactly as the recipe is written, and it wasn't bad. I felt it could use more flavor. All of the bones were there for a great recipe, but some of the ingredients weren't quite enough. 

We've tweaked it and added galanga instead of ginger, and upped the fish sauce and basil quantities. We also like it pretty spicy, so we use minced hot Thai chillis. (Or in a pinch, dry Thai chillis.) The point is though, this won't taste very authentic if you're using American pizzeria chili pepper flakes. (Which I'm not saying is what the recipe actually calls for. It just says red chili flakes, and that can mean a lot of things!)

Superb authentic-type Thai recipe resembles other Thai dishes from cookbook recipes I have prepared previously. Just remember to be careful with the coconut milk, not to burn it. 

Potted Thai holy (Tulsi) basil has strong flavor as strong comparably to ginger. Although more like licorice, I was surprised that it added lemony flavor tones. 

Tip: I recommend if you reconstitute your shiitake mushrooms from dry black mushrooms, add the slices (discarding the stems) during the coconut milk reducing stage.

I used more coconut milk, and added 1 tsp curry powder to the sauce, and at least an additional tsp of red pepper flakes. I didn't have fish sauce. Also used 1 small can of water chestnuts near the end, and a tablespoon of thai chili sauce. My family enjoyed it and I will make this again, possibly adding some broccoli florets to make it a one-dish meal.

We love this. It's on our regular rotation. A few tips: double the liquid ingredients, use fresh peppers (jalapeño, habanero, or Thai hot peppers), and Thai holy basil. The dish goes equally well with noodles, white rice, or brown rice.

tasty, and not too strong for my non-adventurous family. 
I did use corn starch to thicken more, and subbed Chinese broccoli for onions (kids hate onions) . 
served over sticky rice (which I also combined with the left over coconut milk for a quick rice pudding).

This was fantastic. I used most of a can of coconut milk and added and extra tablespoon each of soy sauce and vinegar. Also through in some extra veggies and served over soba noodles. We loved it, thanks!
Added Cilantro, which was a nice touch. I can't figure out how to keep the coconut milks flavor as present as I like it. Any suggestions?
I used the whole can of coconut milk so as not to have leftovers and a little more soy sauce... We absolutely loved it!

Will make again. Very yummy, can be a little salty.

Skipped the mushrooms (personal taste), added the whole can of coconut milk, used pork instead of chicken, used regular basil from our garden. Marinated the meat a little first in a little extra soy sauce, garlic, and ginger.

Made a more low carb version without the rice and it was super - recipe seems very adaptable. Flavors are excellent - used coconut oil instead of olive oil, no fish sauce, visalia onion, baby portabellas, and baby bok choy. Yum!

We gave this a solid 4 stars! Loved the flavors and super easy to make. prep time takes longer than stated if doing all prep by hand and not in a food processor. Followed the recipe exactly and will definitely make it again. DId not think it was salty at all. am wondering if the salt issues others spoke of was do to salting chicken? we will be doubling the sauce and tweaking with some others veggies for the next go round. overall solid, filling, wonderful flavors made for a great dinner last night!
I omitted the mushrooms and it still turned out great.
This was absolutely tasteless. We added 1/8 C of Oyster Sauce and it brought it to life.

item.name: Thai Chicken with Basil Stir Fry

In a bowl, mix the coconut milk, soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, fish sauce, and red pepper flakes.

Stir in the coconut milk sauce. Continue cooking until sauce is reduced be about ⅓. Mix in mushrooms, green onions, and basil, and cook until heated through. Serve over the cooked rice.

c6a130056bec673759f70361b197ebdceada1b4c.name: Slow Cooker BBQ Pulled Pork
c6a130056bec673759f70361b197ebdceada1b4c.description: If you’ve spent any time on Pinterest or food blogs, you’ve likely come across a recipe for three-ingredient barbecue pulled pork that can be made in the slow cooker. Methods and ingredients vary, but the recipe almost always calls for boneless pork shoulder, some sort of dark cola (usually Dr Pepper or root beer) and barbecue sauce. Dubious? We were too, so we asked the members of our NYT Cooking Community Facebook page if anyone had ever made it and if they liked it. We received more than 150 very opinionated responses. Many readers have come up with their own clever twists, like using coffee or beer in place of cola, adding onions or chipotles, rubbing the meat with a spice blend and searing the meat before cooking. We tried cooking it a few different ways and found we liked this adaptation best. It calls for a few more ingredients and an extra step or two, but it’s got layers of flavor and it’s still mostly fuss-free. (You can find the pressure-cooker version of this recipe here.)

ingredients.ingredient: black pepper, plus more to taste
to 4 pound boneless pork shoulder or pork butt, trimmed of most of its excess fat
vegetable oil, plus additional for greasing
(12-ounce) can dark soda, like Dr Pepper, root beer, cola or birch beer
to 1 ½ cups homemade or store-bought barbecue sauce

c6a130056bec673759f70361b197ebdceada1b4c.author: Margaux Laskey

original.name: Slow Cooker BBQ Pulled Pork
original.description: If you’ve spent any time on Pinterest or food blogs, you’ve likely come across a recipe for three-ingredient barbecue pulled pork that can be made in the slow cooker. Methods and ingredients vary, but the recipe almost always calls for boneless pork shoulder, some sort of dark cola (usually Dr Pepper or root beer) and barbecue sauce. Dubious? We were too, so we asked the members of our NYT Cooking Community Facebook page if anyone had ever made it and if they liked it. We received more than 150 very opinionated responses. Many readers have come up with their own clever twists, like using coffee or beer in place of cola, adding onions or chipotles, rubbing the meat with a spice blend and searing the meat before cooking. We tried cooking it a few different ways and found we liked this adaptation best. It calls for a few more ingredients and an extra step or two, but it’s got layers of flavor and it’s still mostly fuss-free. (You can find the pressure-cooker version of this recipe here.)
original.recipeCategory: meat, sandwiches, main course
original.keywords: freezer friendly, paprika, pork shoulder, slow cooker, soda
recipeIngredient: 2 teaspoons hot or sweet smoked paprika
2 teaspoons salt, plus more to taste
1 teaspoon black pepper, plus more to taste
3 to 4 pound boneless pork shoulder or pork butt, trimmed of most of its excess fat
2 tablespoons vegetable oil, plus additional for greasing
1 (12-ounce) can dark soda, like Dr Pepper, root beer, cola or birch beer
1/2 to 1 1/2 cups homemade or store-bought barbecue sauce

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, combine the garlic and onion powders, smoked paprika, salt and black pepper. Rub the spice mixture all over the pork. If you have time, cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 2 hours or up to overnight. If you don’t, no worries; proceed to Step 2.

Lightly grease the crock of a slow cooker. Heat 2 tablespoons vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high. Sear the pork until golden brown on all sides, about 2 minutes each side. Add onion, if using, to the slow cooker. Add the pork on top of the onion. Pour soda over the pork and set the slow cooker to low for 6 to 8 hours, until the meat has collapsed and shreds easily.

Drain most of the liquid from the slow cooker and shred the meat directly in the pot. Add about 1/2 cup of the barbecue sauce and stir to combine. (At this point, if you like crisp bits in your pulled pork, you can spread the shredded pork on a sheet pan and place under a broiler for a couple minutes then return to the slow cooker.) Taste and add more barbecue sauce, hot sauce, salt or pepper, if desired. Serve with soft rolls and extra sauce on the side.

Lightly grease the crock of a slow cooker. Heat 2 tablespoons vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high. Sear the pork until golden brown on all sides, about 2 minutes each side. Add onion, if using, to the slow cooker. Add the pork on top of the onion. Pour soda over the pork and set the slow cooker to low for 6 to 8 hours, until the meat has collapsed and shreds easily.

Drain most of the liquid from the slow cooker and shred the meat directly in the pot. Add about ½ cup of the barbecue sauce and stir to combine. (At this point, if you like crisp bits in your pulled pork, you can spread the shredded pork on a sheet pan and place under a broiler for a couple minutes then return to the slow cooker.) Taste and add more barbecue sauce, hot sauce, salt or pepper, if desired. Serve with soft rolls and extra sauce on the side.

cdb401bd7475fe1228534c0df6037590ac33bd9e.name: Butter-Roasted Paneer With Tomato Curry
cdb401bd7475fe1228534c0df6037590ac33bd9e.description: Roasting mild paneer with yogurt and ghee (or butter) gives it a complex, toasty flavor that’s balanced by the spices and gentle acidity of a quickly made tomato curry. This recipe is adapted from Anita Jaisinghani of Pondicheri in Houston. She prepares her own paneer several times a week to use in curries, salads and crumbled over roasted vegetables. But store-bought paneer will work well here and makes this satisfying dish supremely weeknight friendly. Serve it with rice or flatbread on the side, if you like, to catch the heady sauce. If you have dried fenugreek leaves, you can crumble a tablespoon or so into the curry right at the end.

ingredients.ingredient: to 1 ¼ pounds paneer, cut into 1-inch cubes (2 to 3 packages, depending on size)
to 6 tablespoons plain whole-milk Greek yogurt
Kosher salt (such as Diamond Crystal) and freshly ground black pepper
neutral oil, such as vegetable, safflower or grapeseed oil
garlic cloves, minced or finely grated
finely grated fresh ginger (from about ¾-inch piece)
Pinch of ground cayenne or red-pepper flakes
coarsely chopped cilantro leaves and tender stems, plus more for garnish

cdb401bd7475fe1228534c0df6037590ac33bd9e.author: Melissa Clark

original.name: Butter-Roasted Paneer With Tomato Curry
original.description: Roasting mild paneer with yogurt and ghee (or butter) gives it a complex, toasty flavor that’s balanced by the spices and gentle acidity of a quickly made tomato curry. This recipe is adapted from Anita Jaisinghani of Pondicheri in Houston. She prepares her own paneer several times a week to use in curries, salads and crumbled over roasted vegetables. But store-bought paneer will work well here and makes this satisfying dish supremely weeknight friendly. Serve it with rice or flatbread on the side, if you like, to catch the heady sauce. If you have dried fenugreek leaves, you can crumble a tablespoon or so into the curry right at the end.
original.recipeCategory: dinner, weeknight, curries, main course
original.keywords: canned plum tomatoes, cardamom, cilantro, garam masala, paneer, vegetarian
recipeIngredient: 1 to 1 1/4 pounds paneer, cut into 1-inch cubes (2 to 3 packages, depending on size)
5 to 6 tablespoons plain whole-milk Greek yogurt
3 tablespoons ghee or unsalted butter, melted
Kosher salt (such as Diamond Crystal) and freshly ground black pepper
2 tablespoons neutral oil, such as vegetable, safflower or grapeseed oil
3 garlic cloves, minced or finely grated
2 teaspoons finely grated fresh ginger (from about 3/4-inch piece)
Pinch of ground cayenne or red-pepper flakes
1/2 cup coarsely chopped cilantro leaves and tender stems, plus more for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oven to 400 degrees and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

In a mixing bowl, combine paneer, 3 tablespoons yogurt and ghee. Toss until paneer is well coated, then spread it in a single layer on the prepared baking sheet. Sprinkle lightly with a pinch of salt and black pepper. Roast until the edges are golden, about 13 to 18 minutes.

While the paneer is in the oven, make the tomato curry: In a large skillet, heat oil over medium-high. Add cumin, fenugreek (if using), cardamom and cinnamon, and let cook until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes. Add onions and sauté until tender and translucent, about 5 minutes. Stir in garlic, ginger, 1 teaspoon garam masala, turmeric, cayenne and 1/2 teaspoon salt, and cook until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes.

Using the back of a wooden spoon or your hands, break up tomatoes into pieces and add them, along with their liquid, to the skillet. Reduce heat to a simmer and stir to combine, scraping any browned bits from the bottom of the skillet. Cook until the mixture has thickened slightly, 6 to 8 minutes.

Remove the pan from the heat and stir in cilantro, remaining 1 teaspoon garam masala, and 2 to 3 tablespoons of yogurt, depending on how creamy you want your sauce. Taste and season with more salt and pepper, if needed.

Add paneer to pan and gently toss until well coated. Let paneer sit in the sauce for at least 10 minutes to absorb its flavors. Reheat gently over low heat, if needed. Garnish with more cilantro and serve.

d8126c0c5e902ec4bc5bdc29854fc6073416bed8.name: Greek Stuffed Eggplant (Melitzanes Papoutsakia)
d8126c0c5e902ec4bc5bdc29854fc6073416bed8.description: Make Greek stuffed eggplant (melitzanes papoutsakia). The eggplant is filled with ground beef mixture and topped with bechamel sauce.

ingredients.ingredient: garlic (minced; if garlic is a problem, substitute with 2 to 3 scallions)
kefalotyri cheese (or pecorino or parmesan, grated)

d8126c0c5e902ec4bc5bdc29854fc6073416bed8.author: Nancy Gaifyllia

original.headline: Greek Stuffed Eggplant (Melitzanes Papoutsakia)
original.description: Make Greek stuffed eggplant (melitzanes papoutsakia). The eggplant is filled with ground beef mixture and topped with bechamel sauce.
original.name: Greek Stuffed Eggplant (Melitzanes Papoutsakia)
original.keywords: eggplant
recipeIngredient: 6 small eggplants (6 to 7 inches long each)
2 cloves garlic (minced; if garlic is a problem, substitute with 2 to 3 scallions)
2 cups tomatoes (peeled, cored, and finely chopped)
1 cup kefalotyri cheese (or pecorino or parmesan, grated)

recipeInstructions.name: Steps to Make It

itemListElement.text: Wash and dry the eggplants, trim off stems, and cut in half, lengthwise. With a small knife or spoon, scoop out the pulp of the eggplant, leaving a shell about 1/8 inch thick. Take care not to break through the skin of the eggplant. ( Note: If you haven't done this before, take your time. The pulp will be chopped up and used in the filling, so it can come out a piece at a time.)
Using a spoon,  scoop out seeds from the center and discard. Start at the center of the eggplant half and work your way outward.
Using a knife, remove and discard seeds, then carefully slice around the edge, leaving a small layer of pulp next to the skin; continue to cut, moving in toward the center.
Chop the pulp and set it aside.
Preheat a large frying pan (with cover) on low heat.

When the frying pan has preheated, increase the heat and sauté the onions (both types if you're using scallions instead of garlic) in 2 tablespoons of olive oil, using the frying pan that has the cover.

When the onions soften and turn translucent (without browning), add the chopped eggplant pulp and stir for 2 to 3 minutes. Stir in the ground beef and sauté until it starts to brown. Stir in tomatoes, parsley, garlic, pinches of salt and pepper (to taste), and reduce heat. Simmer covered for 20 minutes or until the sauce melds and the liquid is absorbed. Remove from the heat, and set aside.

recipeInstructions.name: For the Bechamel Sauce:

itemListElement.text: Preparation: In a saucepan, melt the butter on low heat. As soon as it starts to bubble (not brown) add the flour and stir with a wooden spoon until there are no lumps, Add the milk slowly, stirring constantly with a whisk, until the sauce begins to thicken - creamy without being too thick (it will thicken further after removing from the heat). Remove from the heat and stir in salt, pepper, and nutmeg. Allow the sauce to cool for a few minutes before stirring in the egg yolk until well blended.
Preheat oven to 350 F/180 C.
Preheat a second frying pan over low heat. Increase heat when ready to sauté the eggplant.

Lightly sauté the eggplant halves in olive oil in the second frying pan. Start with a little oil (3 tablespoons) but have more at hand since eggplant absorbs a lot of oil and the pan could dry out. This step is simply to soften the eggplant a bit, so sauté quickly on both sides, remove, and drain on a rack (do not wipe off the oil).

Place the eggplant halves on the bottom of a baking or roasting pan. Sprinkle some of the cheese to cover the bottom of the well in the eggplant, then spoon in the filling to the top of the side rims. Spoon over the béchamel sauce (about 1 tablespoon for each piece), and place a slice of tomato on top. When all the eggplants are finished, sprinkle the remaining grated cheese over the top.
Cook on the lowest oven rack setting until the béchamel is browned, the cheese on top is browned, and the eggplants are soft, 1 to 1 1/2 hours.
Remove the eggplants from the pan with a spatula and serve warm.

recipeInstructions.name: Alternative Preparation

itemListElement.text: For the less chunky sauce, when preparing the tomatoes, onions, and eggplant pulp, either use a food processor or grate them to make smaller pulpy pieces. Use with their liquids. Reduce simmer time to 10 to 15 minutes as it will take a little less time for the sauce to meld.

Some versions don't call for the tomato slice on top. If you don't use it, just sprinkle the remaining cheese on top of the béchamel and cook the same way for 1 to 1 1/2 hours or until the béchamel browns and the eggplants are soft.

review.reviewBody: I made it today. The meat/pulp was a bit bland, so to make it more aromatic and "Greek", I added dried oregano, fennel and mint.
Absolutely delicious and flavorful! I wanted a recipe that was like the stuffed eggplant dish that I had at our local Greek festival. This definitely was close to it!

dd2d6049f31c9dae6faa9941effcce6d21d72cdd.name: Lasagna alla Bolognese (Meat-Sauce Lasagna) Recipe
dd2d6049f31c9dae6faa9941effcce6d21d72cdd.description: A recipe for a classic, hearty Northern Italian-style lasagna (Lasagne alla Bolognese).

ingredients.ingredient: batches (4 cups) besciamella  sauce ( recipe here)

batches Bolognese sauce or Tuscan-Style Ragù sauce  (double the ingredients in the besciamella recipe linked above and in either meat-sauce recipe to make a large 9"x13" or 8"x11" lasagna, or use just 1 batch of besciamella (2 cups) and 1 batch of either meat sauce to make a smaller, 6"x10" lasagna)

9-ounce box of no-boil/oven-ready lasagna noodles (or 1 pound of fresh lasagna sheets, preferable) [Note: if you are using dried, no-boil lasagna noodles, your sauces should be more liquid; if you use fresh noodles, your sauces should be drier]

dd2d6049f31c9dae6faa9941effcce6d21d72cdd.author: Danette St. Onge

original.headline: Lasagna alla Bolognese (Meat-Sauce Lasagna) Recipe
original.description: A recipe for a classic, hearty Northern Italian-style lasagna (Lasagne alla Bolognese).
original.name: Lasagna alla Bolognese (Meat-Sauce Lasagna) Recipe
original.keywords: sauce
recipeIngredient: 2 batches (4 cups) besciamella  sauce ( recipe here)

2 batches Bolognese sauce or Tuscan-Style Ragù sauce  (double the ingredients in the besciamella recipe linked above and in either meat-sauce recipe to make a large 9"x13" or 8"x11" lasagna, or use just 1 batch of besciamella (2 cups) and 1 batch of either meat sauce to make a smaller, 6"x10" lasagna)

1 9-ounce box of no-boil/oven-ready lasagna noodles (or 1 pound of fresh lasagna sheets, preferable) [Note: if you are using dried, no-boil lasagna noodles, your sauces should be more liquid; if you use fresh noodles, your sauces should be drier]
1 cup Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese (freshly and finely grated)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius).
Prepare the besciamella sauce and your meat sauce of choice according to the recipes and instructions linked above.
Cover the bottom of your lasagna pan with a thin, even layer of besciamella sauce.
Cover the besciamella sauce with a layer of the lasagna noodles (you may overlap them slightly to make them fit, and/or cut them so they fit).
Cover the noodles with another thin layer of besciamella sauce, then a layer of the meat sauce, then a generous sprinkling of the grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese.

Then lay down another layer of the noodles, then besciamella, meat sauce, and grated cheese, and repeat: noodles, besciamella, meat sauce, grated cheese until you reach the top of your pan. Usually this will be between 4 to 6 layers.

Finish with a layer of meat sauce, besciamella, and another generous sprinkling of grated Parmigiano. [Note: If you are using dry, no-boil pasta, make sure that it is all completely covered with sauce or it won't cook.]
Bake for 20 to 30 minutes, or until the top is crisp and golden brown.

If you have any leftover ragù   sauce, it freezes very well. The lasagne can be made ahead of time and kept refrigerated and reheated in the oven, or assembled and frozen uncooked, then defrosted in the refrigerator for 24 hours before cooking.

e646dd28ed73b208dc9fa8e1b834dd8b5d9708da.name: Coconut Red Curry With Tofu
e646dd28ed73b208dc9fa8e1b834dd8b5d9708da.description: This simple weeknight red curry relies on jarred or canned red curry paste for flavor, which you can find at larger supermarkets and specialty markets. Transfer leftover canned curry paste to a jar, top it with a little oil and store in the refrigerator for up to a month. Or freeze for longer storage. Feel free to substitute other vegetables for the mushrooms and snow peas, though you might have to increase the cooking time slightly if using something dense like carrot or cubed winter squash.

ingredients.ingredient: inch ginger root, peeled and minced
Thai chile or 2 serrano peppers, seeded and thinly sliced
Basil and/or cilantro leaves, for garnish
Brown or white rice, for serving

e646dd28ed73b208dc9fa8e1b834dd8b5d9708da.author: Melissa Clark

original.name: Coconut Red Curry With Tofu
original.description: This simple weeknight red curry relies on jarred or canned red curry paste for flavor, which you can find at larger supermarkets and specialty markets. Transfer leftover canned curry paste to a jar, top it with a little oil and store in the refrigerator for up to a month. Or freeze for longer storage. Feel free to substitute other vegetables for the mushrooms and snow peas, though you might have to increase the cooking time slightly if using something dense like carrot or cubed winter squash.
original.recipeCategory: dinner, lunch, quick, weeknight, curries, main course
original.keywords: coconut milk, cremini, extra-firm tofu, red curry paste, snow peas
recipeIngredient: 1 Thai chile or 2 serrano peppers, seeded and thinly sliced
1/2 teaspoon sea salt, more to taste
Basil and/or cilantro leaves, for garnish
Brown or white rice, for serving

recipeInstructions.text: Cut tofu into 1-inch slabs and place on paper towel-lined baking sheet. Cover with another layer of paper towels and place another baking sheet on top. Let sit for 20 minutes. Cut into 1-inch cubes.

Heat oil in a large skillet over medium high heat. Add ginger, shallots, garlic, chile and cilantro stems, and sauté until tender, about 5 minutes. Add mushrooms and sauté until golden brown and tender, about 5 minutes. Season with salt. Stir in curry paste and cook 2 minutes. Pour in coconut milk, scraping up any curry paste with a wooden spoon. Add fish sauce, lime zest and juice. Add tofu cubes and snow peas. Simmer until the sauce thickens slightly and the snow peas are tender, 7 to 10 minutes, stirring frequently. Taste and add more salt and/or fish sauce if needed.
Serve warm with brown rice and a scattering of torn basil and/or cilantro leaves on top.

instructionList: Cut tofu into 1-inch slabs and place on paper towel-lined baking sheet. Cover with another layer of paper towels and place another baking sheet on top. Let sit for 20 minutes. Cut into 1-inch cubes.

e8f7b16fdc015d46f514e67eab3e636103b218b9.name: The Best Eggplant Parmesan
e8f7b16fdc015d46f514e67eab3e636103b218b9.description: I love eggplant and have many recipes that include it, but this one is my favorite. The seasonings make this dish unforgettable. —Dottie Kilpatrick, Wilmington, North Carolina

ingredients.ingredient: thinly sliced fresh basil leaves or 1 tablespoon dried basil
minced fresh oregano or 1 teaspoon dried oregano
eggplants (about 1 pound each), peeled and cut lengthwise into ½-inch slices
¼ cups shredded Parmesan cheese, divided
thinly sliced fresh basil leaves or 2 tablespoons dried basil

e8f7b16fdc015d46f514e67eab3e636103b218b9.author: Taste of Home

original.name: The Best Eggplant Parmesan
original.description: I love eggplant and have many recipes that include it, but this one is my favorite. The seasonings make this dish unforgettable. —Dottie Kilpatrick, Wilmington, North Carolina
recipeIngredient: 1/4 cup thinly sliced fresh basil leaves or 1 tablespoon dried basil
1 tablespoon minced fresh oregano or 1 teaspoon dried oregano
4 small eggplants (about 1 pound each), peeled and cut lengthwise into 1/2-inch slices
1/2 cup thinly sliced fresh basil leaves or 2 tablespoons dried basil
original.recipeInstructions: In a Dutch oven over medium heat, cook garlic in oil 1 minute. Stir in tomatoes, olives, basil, capers, pepper flakes and pepper. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, 45-60 minutes or until thickened.,    Meanwhile, for eggplant, place flour and beaten eggs in separate shallow bowls. In another bowl, combine  bread crumbs, garlic powder and oregano. Dip eggplant in flour, eggs, then bread crumb mixture.,    In a large skillet, cook eggplant in batches in oil until tender, 5 minutes on each side. Drain on paper towels. In a bowl, combine the eggs, ricotta cheese, 1/2 cup Parmesan cheese, basil and pepper.,    Preheat the oven to 350°. In each of 2 greased 13x9-in. baking dishes, layer 1-1/2 cups tomato sauce, 4 eggplant slices, 1 cup ricotta mixture and 2 cups mozzarella cheese. Repeat layers, sprinkling each with remaining the Parmesan cheese. Bake, uncovered, 35-40 minutes or until bubbly. Let stand for 10 minutes before cutting. If desired, sprinkle with additional fresh basil.

review.reviewBody: I made this today with eggplant from the garden and it is a stellar recipe! I put my eggplant in the air fryer to eliminate any extra Grease and it was simply amazing. This is worth the time and effort.  Not too bad with two people in the kitchen. I could see How some people might enjoy mushrooms in it or on it as well. I used fresh herbs from the garden which made it heaven in your mouth.

We grew eggplant in our garden for the first time this year and when I told friends that I didn't know what to make with them, all said.. Eggplant Parmesan!! I'm thrilled that this is the recipe that I tried. Although it was time consuming and labor intensive it was absolutely AMAZING!! I used up our first-ever eggplants and shared the second casserole with friends! My husband liked it so well that he asked if eggplants were sold at the grocery store and if so, could we get them year round! I will definitely be making this again! Delicious!
Truly delicious, loved it and so did all the people that I shared it with.  I topped it with some fresh mushrooms that I saut?ed in rosemary olive oil, minced garlic, salt, pepper and butter.

Oh my goodness, I was getting frustrated while I making this because it was taking sooo long- but after the first bite, I was thrilled I made it!!  Well worth the work!  I absolutely loved it!!  So did my family!  My husband absolutely does not like eggplant at all.  We didn't tell him what he was eating- he thought it was lasgana.  He had seconds and then we told him.  My one son hates vegetables, but will try somethings.  He loved it, too!  Even my fussy 11 year-old ate every bite!!  We will make this again!!  Thanks for the WONDERFUL recipe!  It was WORTH all the work!

I followed this recipe exactly as it was written.  I definately took note of the folks that stated they broiled the eggplant rather then fried it.  However I wanted to try the recipe prior to tweeking it.  This was one of the best eggplant parmesan recepies I have made.  Next time around I would add more red pepper as I like spicy.  I would NOT subsitute  a store bought spaghetti sauce.. NOOO WAY :) I used eggplant from our garden.  Spend the extra time making this, it's WORTH the time!
Absolutely delicious!  It's not my normal "quick" dish, but it is well worth all the effort.
I love this recipe! I make it every summer with fresh egg plant out of my garden, yum. thanks for sharing this recipe. It really is The Best Eggplant Parmesan.:-)
Alfoa, almost every eggplant parmesan  is cut lengthwise. This is very much likeTyler Perry's recipe from Foodnetwork.com but he doesn't peel the eggplant just trims the ends.

I also just made half of the recipe and it was so delicious! If you do decide to make just half I think only getting one eggplant is enough. Instead of cutting it length wise we cut it into circles and we ended up not needing the other eggplant. Other than that we stuck to the directions and were VERY pleased with the outcome. I am not a beginner cook but surely am not a great chef but that being said, even though this does take a little more prep time than usual, it is not difficult. This is sure to be a crowd pleaser at any meal!
this is simply, the BEST!  well worth the extra time.  the directions are great.  Only change made was to substitute 1/2 panko for the 3c of bread crumbs.   Fabulous!! Thank you!

this was my first time cooking with eggplant and it was so delicious that it earned me a facebook shoutout from my brothers :) making it again tonight for my bosses, thats how confident i am in the amazingness of this recipe!
This was truly the best! It does take a lot of time, but it is worth it!
My family loved this recipe and i will certainly make it again when time allows!  It's delicious!

A truely delicious recipe. I made a half recipe as there are only 2 of us. It takes a little time to make but my wife and i thought the dish had a great texture and outstanding flavor well worth the effort. Will definately make again.WalterMyrtle beach, SC
this eggplant parmesan is SOOOOOO  Good!!!!
This is almost identical to my ages-old recipe, but I never thought to add olives and capers. Inspired idea...delicious!

This recipe is really good just not that good for you. I lightened it up with light ricotta and 2 1/2 C of cheese per 9x13 pan. I cut the oil back in the sauce but by all means make the sauce it was one of the best parts. I also baked the eggplants after coating them. Put them on a greased sheet bake at 350 for 30 min turning once. I am trying to go gluten free for a while so I substituted gluten free flour. mix for the white flour and crushed rice chex cereal for the bread crumbs. Worked just fine and nobody even knew. My kids ate it and my girlfriends loved it. Will make again.
Just a hint to those who had trouble making the crumbs stick, next time use Panko flecks and press a little.
It's really good.  And easy to freeze half of it for a smaller family.

e8f7b16fdc015d46f514e67eab3e636103b218b9.instructionText: In a Dutch oven over medium heat, cook garlic in oil 1 minute. Stir in tomatoes, olives, basil, capers, pepper flakes and pepper. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, 45-60 minutes or until thickened.,    Meanwhile, for eggplant, place flour and beaten eggs in separate shallow bowls. In another bowl, combine  bread crumbs, garlic powder and oregano. Dip eggplant in flour, eggs, then bread crumb mixture.,    In a large skillet, cook eggplant in batches in oil until tender, 5 minutes on each side. Drain on paper towels. In a bowl, combine the eggs, ricotta cheese, ½ cup Parmesan cheese, basil and pepper.,    Preheat the oven to 350°. In each of 2 greased 13x9-in. baking dishes, layer 1-½ cups tomato sauce, 4 eggplant slices, 1 cup ricotta mixture and 2 cups mozzarella cheese. Repeat layers, sprinkling each with remaining the Parmesan cheese. Bake, uncovered, 35-40 minutes or until bubbly. Let stand for 10 minutes before cutting. If desired, sprinkle with additional fresh basil.

f3a1b98da84ab0facca2ddcf5136d92ccc285983.name: Miso-Honey Chicken and Asparagus
f3a1b98da84ab0facca2ddcf5136d92ccc285983.description: This quick and easy sheet-pan meal is broiled instead of baked, which chars the marinade slightly on the chicken, browns the asparagus for maximum flavor and cuts the cooking time to around 10 minutes. The miso-honey mixture packs a punch, with lots of garlic, ginger and as much hot sauce as you like. It doubles as a marinade for the chicken and a sauce to spoon over the chicken and asparagus once cooked. Make sure to arrange the chicken thighs in a single layer, so they cook and char evenly, and keep an eye on the pan, as some broilers have hot spots. Feel free to substitute broccolini for the asparagus, and serve with steamed rice, if desired.

ingredients.ingredient: chile-garlic sauce or other hot sauce
to 2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken thighs

f3a1b98da84ab0facca2ddcf5136d92ccc285983.author: Yossy Arefi

original.name: Miso-Honey Chicken and Asparagus
original.description: This quick and easy sheet-pan meal is broiled instead of baked, which chars the marinade slightly on the chicken, browns the asparagus for maximum flavor and cuts the cooking time to around 10 minutes. The miso-honey mixture packs a punch, with lots of garlic, ginger and as much hot sauce as you like. It doubles as a marinade for the chicken and a sauce to spoon over the chicken and asparagus once cooked. Make sure to arrange the chicken thighs in a single layer, so they cook and char evenly, and keep an eye on the pan, as some broilers have hot spots. Feel free to substitute broccolini for the asparagus, and serve with steamed rice, if desired.
original.recipeCategory: dinner, easy, quick, weeknight, poultry, main course
original.keywords: asparagus, chicken thigh, honey, miso, sheet-pan, soy sauce
recipeIngredient: 2 teaspoons chile-garlic sauce or other hot sauce
1 1/2 to 2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken thighs

recipeInstructions.text: Make the marinade: In a bowl, whisk together the miso, honey, soy sauce, rice vinegar, ginger, garlic, chile-garlic sauce, 1 tablespoon oil and 1 tablespoon water. Refrigerate half the marinade for serving.

Place the chicken in a shallow dish or zip-top bag and pour the remaining marinade over the top. Toss the chicken until coated and let marinate in the refrigerator for up to 30 minutes. (A longer marinade may dry out the chicken.)
When you are ready to cook, heat the broiler with a rack set 6 inches below it. Line a large baking sheet with aluminum foil.

Remove the chicken from the marinade, scraping off and discarding any excess. Place the chicken in a single layer on one side of the baking sheet, with the flatter side up. Place the asparagus on the other side. Drizzle the asparagus with remaining oil, then season the asparagus; toss to coat.
Broil until the chicken is cooked through with some charred spots and the asparagus is browned, about 10 minutes.
To serve, top the chicken with a drizzle of the reserved marinade and a sprinkle of scallions. Serve with rice, if desired.

f90319560eb2b38c243a5f8297867e6c12e61ad2.name: Thai Basil Pork Recipe

ingredients.ingredient: Ground or minced pork, chicken, beef, or tofu (mushroom would be good too)
Thai chili (add less if you like mild)
Thai sweet or holy basil (Approximately 2 to 3 oz.)
Tbs. Thai dark sweet soy sauce

f90319560eb2b38c243a5f8297867e6c12e61ad2.author: Seonkyoung Longest

original.name: Thai Basil Pork Recipe
recipeIngredient: 8 oz. Ground or minced pork, chicken, beef, or tofu (mushroom would be good too)
5 Thai chili (add less if you like mild)
2 Cups Thai sweet or holy basil (Approximately 2 to 3 oz.)
1 Tbs. Thai dark sweet soy sauce

recipeInstructions.text: Roughly chop garlic and chili, set aside. Take basil leaves from stem and set aside.
In a small mixing bowl, add all ingredients for the sauce and whisk until sugar has dissolved; set aside.
Heat a wok over high heat, add 2 Tbs. cooking oil. Add garlic and chili; stir fry until fragrance about1 minute. Make sure not to burn garlic.
Add pork, and stir fry for 1 to 2 minutes or until pork is 3/4 way cooked.
Pour sauce into wok and stir fry until pork absorbed about 30 second to 1 minute.
Stir in basil and remove from heat.
Fry egg with enough oil, almost like deep frying. Pour oil over egg with an wooden spoon so you don’t have to flip over egg.
Place Thai basil on a serving place and place fried egg right on top.
Serve with lime wedges and warm cooked Jasmine rice. Enjoy! [/url]

fb62b768aa844587d534405c3ac1332b13f400dc.name: Moroccan Zaalouk (Cooked Eggplant and Tomato Salad)
fb62b768aa844587d534405c3ac1332b13f400dc.description: Moroccan zaalouk is a delicious, cooked salad made with eggplant, tomatoes, garlic, olive oil, and spices. It's usually served as a dip with crusty bread.
fb62b768aa844587d534405c3ac1332b13f400dc.author: Christine Benlafquih

original.headline: Moroccan Zaalouk (Cooked Eggplant and Tomato Salad)
original.description: Moroccan zaalouk is a delicious, cooked salad made with eggplant, tomatoes, garlic, olive oil, and spices. It's usually served as a dip with crusty bread.
citation: U.S. Department of Agriculture. Agricultural Research Service. FoodData Central, &#34;<a href="https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/1103353/nutrients" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="externalLink" data-ordinal="1">Eggplant, Raw</a>.&#34; 30 Oct. 2020.
original.name: Moroccan Zaalouk (Cooked Eggplant and Tomato Salad)
original.keywords: Tomato
recipeIngredient: 4 large tomatoes, peeled, seeded, and chopped

recipeInstructions.text: Gather the ingredients.

Combine eggplant, tomatoes, garlic, cilantro, parsley, paprika, cumin, salt, oil, water, and cayenne in a large deep skillet or pot. Cover and simmer over medium to medium-high heat for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
With a spoon or potato masher, crush and blend tomatoes and eggplant.
Add lemon wedge to the pot, if using. Continue simmering mixture, uncovered, for 10 minutes. The lemon will give a tangy nuance but is not necessary.
The zaalouk is ready when liquids are reduced and mixture can be stirred into a heap in the center of the pan.
Drizzle olive oil—or chile oil if you like spicy food. Serve with sliced crusty bread.

review.reviewBody: I have made this several times since someone directed me to this recipe and like it a lot. I use it when I am hungry for a relatively low calorie snack on a cracker. Regarding the recipe, I never worked out how much eggplant is a large one so I have been using around 2.5 pounds. I think this may be a bit much because when I last made this and increased the amount of cumin and garlic, it tasted even better. I have made some short cuts to the recipe after I first made it according to what was written here. Instead of 4 large tomatoes, I now use a can of diced tomatoes which I think works just as well. While I started out with fresh parsley, I now use about 2 tablespoons of dried and it turns out well too with less hassle. It doesn't take me long to make this recipe and I have even less time due to a chopper I use for the eggplant.
I made zaalouk today using your recipe. I roasted it on the grill first. Put it in a skillet to finish it off. My family will break fast with this tonight. Thank you
89 carbs per serving?!! That's a lot of carbs for a snack! Is that mostly from the bread?
Can this be frozen? How long does it stay in the fridge?

Have just made this for the first time, and although it was absolutely delicious, when i make it again i won't add any water. The aubergine and tomato released SO MUCH LIQUID it took about an hour to reduce even though the veg was completely tender and broken down! I will also try reserving half of the herbs to stir through once its cooked for a bit of freshness.

instructionList: Preheat oven to 350° F. Grease an 8x10 (or similar) baking dish and set aside.
In a large bowl, stir together the oats, flour, seeds, salt, spices, pepper, cheeses, and sun-dried tomatoes.
Add the eggs and oil and stir until fully incorporated.
Press the dough into the prepared baking dish in an even layer. Sprinkle with the remaining parmesan cheese.
Bake for 25-30 minutes, until bars are firm and browned.
Let cool completely, then cut into 12 bars and remove from the pan.
Store in a sealed container in the fridge for up to a week, or in the freezer for up to a month.
